Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Waste Valorization through Hydrothermal Catalytic Conversion of Carboxylic Acids/Esters to Hydrocarbon Fuels

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1438218
PI: Strathmann, Timothy J.

SusChEM: Waste Valorization through Hydrothermal Catalytic Conversion of Carboxylic Acids/Esters to Hydrocarbon Fuels

Population growth and economic development are spurring increases in demand for new sources of energy and chemical precursors while simultaneously producing growing quantities of waste. Concurrently, there is growing agreement that waste streams should be viewed as valuable renewable resources rather than economic burdens. Current wastewater treatment operations are energy intensive, and ~3 % of electrical energy in the U.S. is used for wastewater treatment despite the fact that wastewater contains (1) organic materials possessing several times the energy needed for treatment, and (2) nutrients that can be used as a source to cultivate many times more organic biomass (e.g., through algae cultivation). When viewed in a biorefinery concept where the value of individual process streams is maximized, wastewater treatment provides an opportunity to produce energy and valuable chemicals while meeting treatment goals. Environmental engineers are uniquely positioned to play a central role in valorizing waste streams, developing new technologies that meet environmental quality goals while simultaneously recovering and producing energy, platform chemical feed stocks, and nutrients. The overall objective of the project is to advance hydrothermal catalytic technologies for converting waste-derived carboxylic acid/ester feed-stocks to hydrocarbon fuels. Development of economical technologies for valorizing waste streams has significant potential to transform waste treatment practices. Improved technologies for conversion of biomass-derived organics in water would also have broader impacts for the nascent lignocellulosic and algal biorefining industries, where feedstock dewatering/drying is a major hurdle to economic viability. This project will contribute to the training of at least two graduate students and will be used as a vehicle for recruiting and mentoring underrepresented minority undergraduate researchers. In addition, project participants will contribute to an environmental engineering and sustainability camp for high school girls that the I directs, at the University.

The proposed work supports larger collaborative efforts targeting development of integrated biological-catalytic pathways that are potentially transformative for valorization of municipal, agricultural, and industrial waste streams, including large quantities of organic wastes expected from proposed cellulosic biorefineries. Conversion of feedstocks in water is ideal because it eliminates the need for cost- and energy-prohibitive dewatering/drying steps. This study will be one of the first to focus on developing catalysts capable of sustained activity for both deoxygenation of waste-derived carboxylic acids/esters and in situ production of hydrogen to meet process needs. Proposed work will also improve understanding of the mechanisms responsible for catalyst deactivation and identify preventative and regeneration strategies for sustaining catalyst activity. A series of tasks were outlined to include examine catalysts with different combinations of lower-cost primary and secondary metals and to be compared for their dual functionality (acid/ester deoxygenation and in situ hydrogen generation). The most promising catalyst formulations will be extensively characterized, and their activity, longevity and deactivation mechanisms will be studied in detail under continuous-flow conditions in a packed bed reactor with both model compounds and waste-derived feedstock?s. Experimental results will be used as input for techno-economic and life cycle analyses to evaluate valorization potential and environmental sustainability.

Institution.Name: Colorado School of Mines
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work aims to advance the application of innovative catalytic technologies for the purpose of converting organic waste materials like waste vegetable oils into liquid fuels that are directly compatible with petroleum-derived diesel and gasoline fuels. There continues to be growing demands for new sources of fuel at the same time that society is generating growing quantities of solid and liquid wastes. With appropriate technologies, these wastes can be sustainably converted into fuels to reduce environmental burdens of our transportation infrastructure. Conversion of wet waste materials present a special challenge because existing refinery technologies are often incompatible with raw materials possessing high moisture content. This work seeks to overcome this barrier by develop catalysts and conversion strategies that take advantage of water’s unique properties at subcritical hydrothermal conditions (200-350°C, < 22 MPa) to promote chemical conversion of biochemical intermediates into fuel-grade chemicals.

 

This project included experiments examining the conversion of actual waste-derived materials (e.g., vegetable grease, animal processing residuals) and model chemicals to both demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategies and examine the underlying principles and mechanisms that govern the processes. Key outcomes from this work include the identification of effective catalyst formulations and process conditions that can be applied to convert diverse waste organic materials into high value products that can be substituted for petroleum-based products. The most significant outcomes stemmed from work aimed at converting low-value waste lipid sources (e.g., restaurant grease, animal processing residuals) and waste lignin (a byproduct of bioethanol production) directly into diesel- and gasoline-grade hydrocarbon fuels. In addition, we were able to identify new catalysts that can facilitate these reactions that are much lower cost alternatives to the precious metal catalysts previously reported. Finally, we demonstrated that hydrothermal catalytic processing of lipid wastes overcomes one of the major limitations of conventional hydroprocessing, the need to supply significant quantities of hydrogen gas from external sources (typically derived from hydrocarbon reforming). In the hydrothermal reaction environment, the required hydrogen can be generated from a lipid decomposition byproduct (glycerol) by aqueous phase reforming reactions mediated by the same catalyst materials. Ultimately, these research outcomes improve our understanding of hydrothermal reaction mechanisms and serve to advance long-term efforts to improve the sustainability of both waste treatment operations and transportation fuel production.

 

In addition to research outcomes, this project also contributed to the training of a number of graduate and undergraduate students, visiting scholar, and high school students. Graduate students gained valuable experiences mentoring undergraduates through Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) programs and instructing K-12 students in outreach activities. Research was also used in the development and implementation of summer camp activities aimed at promoting female high school student pursuit of environmental engineering and STEM-based careers. Finally, the project served as a platform to engage industry contacts in collaborative efforts to translate research findings into practice.


Last Modified: 10/15/2018
Modified by: Timothy J Strathmann
